file_metadata.title: Open problems in synthetic multicellularity

chunks.text: Multicellularity is a major evolutionary transition enabling complex life. Bioengineering of multicellular systems allows investigation of regeneration, disease, cognition, and behavior. This paper presents open problems and conceptual approaches in the field, focusing on synthetic alternatives like microbial consortia, organoids, and living bots, to understand multicellular complexity across multiple scales.
chunks.chunk_summary: Synthetic multicellularity offers a new approach to understanding complex life, including regeneration, disease, cognition, and behavior.
chunks.authors: ["Ricard Solé", "Nuria Conde-Pueyo", "Jordi Pla-Mauri", "Jordi Garcia-Ojalvo", "Nuria Montserrat", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Life is categorized as unicellular (UC) or multicellular (MC). UC organisms operate independently, while MC organisms exhibit cell specialization and cooperation. MC systems have complex traits like developmental programs and spatial patterns. Synthetic approaches, including microbial consortia, organoids, and living bots, offer insights into MC evolution, including movement and cognition.
chunks.chunk_summary: Multicellular organisms, unlike unicellular ones, exhibit complex traits like cell specialization, cooperation, and developmental programs, which can be studied using synthetic approaches.
chunks.authors: ["Ricard Solé", "Nuria Conde-Pueyo", "Jordi Pla-Mauri", "Jordi Garcia-Ojalvo", "Nuria Montserrat", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Synthetic multicellular systems can be classified into three overlapping categories: synthetic multicellular circuits, programmable synthetic assemblies, and synthetic morphology and agential materials. Synthetic circuits involve genetically engineered cells, often using a modular approach. Programmable assemblies exploit predictable adhesion-driven spatial morphodynamics. Agential materials, like organoids and biobots, exhibit emergent properties at the system level.
chunks.chunk_summary: Synthetic multicellular systems can be classified into three categories: circuits, assemblies, and agential materials, each with distinct properties and applications.
chunks.authors: ["Ricard Solé", "Nuria Conde-Pueyo", "Jordi Pla-Mauri", "Jordi Garcia-Ojalvo", "Nuria Montserrat", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Biological agents, unlike inert matter, perform computations by processing information and responding adaptively. Synthetic biology builds logic circuits, including gates, oscillators, and decision-making networks. However, the "wiring problem" due to cross-talk in complex cellular circuits limits predictability. Multicellular designs offer a combinatorial approach, using distributed computation logic to overcome this limitation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Biological agents perform computations, but the "wiring problem" in complex circuits limits predictability, a challenge addressed by multicellular designs using distributed computation.
chunks.authors: ["Ricard Solé", "Nuria Conde-Pueyo", "Jordi Pla-Mauri", "Jordi Garcia-Ojalvo", "Nuria Montserrat", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Complex multicellular agents require cellular diversity and predictable spatial organization. Cell states are understood through attractors, and synthetic circuits with multiple stable states have been designed. Predictable spatial organization can be achieved through adhesion dynamics, where cells move via energy minimization based on adhesion strengths. This principle explains cell sorting and has led to programmable synthetic morphologies.
chunks.chunk_summary: Predictable spatial organization in multicellular agents can be achieved through adhesion dynamics, where cells move based on adhesion strengths, enabling programmable morphologies.
chunks.authors: ["Ricard Solé", "Nuria Conde-Pueyo", "Jordi Pla-Mauri", "Jordi Garcia-Ojalvo", "Nuria Montserrat", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Predictability decreases in complex systems like organs and organisms due to the nonlinear genotype-phenotype mapping. Organoids offer opportunities to study emergent spatial structures and functionalities, but controlling their development remains a challenge. Xenobots and Anthrobots demonstrate that endogenous functionalities can be achieved without genetic editing, highlighting the potential of agential materials.
chunks.chunk_summary: Predictability decreases in complex systems due to nonlinear genotype-phenotype mapping, but agential materials like Xenobots and Anthrobots offer new approaches to achieving functionalities without genetic editing.
chunks.authors: ["Ricard Solé", "Nuria Conde-Pueyo", "Jordi Pla-Mauri", "Jordi Garcia-Ojalvo", "Nuria Montserrat", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Open problems in synthetic multicellularity include designing synthetic developmental programs, exploring embodied memory and learning beyond standard metaphors, creating synthetic collective intelligence inspired by natural systems, developing synthetic neural cognition through precision neuroengineering, designing synthetic proto-organisms and life cycles, building novel organs, creating multiscale synthetic holobionts, and designing synthetic behavior.
chunks.chunk_summary: Several open problems in synthetic multicellularity include designing developmental programs, exploring embodied memory, creating synthetic collective intelligence, and building novel organs.
chunks.authors: ["Ricard Solé", "Nuria Conde-Pueyo", "Jordi Pla-Mauri", "Jordi Garcia-Ojalvo", "Nuria Montserrat", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Predictability in multicellular designs is a key challenge. Most synthetic systems are designed for in vitro conditions, disconnected from natural cellular circuitry. Organismality imposes constraints on individual cells, involving trade-offs in the evolution of multicellularity. The complexity drain, where cellular functional diversity decreases as functions transfer to the multicellular level, limits top-down engineering approaches.
chunks.chunk_summary: Predictability in multicellular designs is limited by the disconnected nature of in vitro systems and the complexity drain associated with the evolution of multicellularity.
chunks.authors: ["Ricard Solé", "Nuria Conde-Pueyo", "Jordi Pla-Mauri", "Jordi Garcia-Ojalvo", "Nuria Montserrat", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Multicellular complexity arises from a nonlinear genotype-phenotype mapping, requiring consideration of self-organization beyond the gene level. Synthetic biology, organoids, and living robots offer new ways to study emergent properties and agency.  Emergent properties, a key outcome of self-organization, pose challenges for bioengineering macroscopic systems.  Theoretical and computational models help analyze uncertainty in multicellular complexity.
chunks.chunk_summary: Multicellular complexity arises from nonlinear mappings and emergent properties, which can be studied using synthetic biology, organoids, and living robots, aided by theoretical models.
chunks.authors: ["Ricard Solé", "Nuria Conde-Pueyo", "Jordi Pla-Mauri", "Jordi Garcia-Ojalvo", "Nuria Montserrat", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The emergent nature of multicellular complexity may not be an insurmountable obstacle to understanding self-organization. Universal features, such as basic building blocks of developmental complexity and structural properties like body symmetries, may aid in understanding. Synthetic alternatives can help determine whether these commonalities are due to contingencies, optimality, or inevitable emergence.
chunks.chunk_summary: Despite the challenges of emergence, universal features and structural properties may aid in understanding multicellular complexity, and synthetic alternatives can help explore these aspects.
chunks.authors: ["Ricard Solé", "Nuria Conde-Pueyo", "Jordi Pla-Mauri", "Jordi Garcia-Ojalvo", "Nuria Montserrat", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Synthetic biology, organoids, and living robots offer new ways to interrogate nature, considering emergent properties and agency. These tools can bridge the gap between cellular and tissue/organ-level models, providing a more realistic representation of in vivo tissue structures. Organoids allow analysis of emergence and limitations imposed by self-organization, while Xenobots and Anthrobots help understand complex biology at the organismal level. These advancements will be crucial for understanding complexity evolution and developing new approaches to health and disease.
chunks.chunk_summary: Synthetic biology, organoids, and living robots offer powerful tools for understanding multicellular complexity, bridging the gap between cellular and tissue/organ-level models and paving the way for new approaches to health and disease.
